results.title: A Long time dream
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The diversity of remote Aboriginal tribes is vast and complex. Between them they speak fifty languages, live in 1,000 communities and number some 54,000 people. This program looks at some of the ways these communities have related to white society. Some communities live a superficially western style of life, yet cling to their tribal laws and customs. Others have developed social problems such as alcoholism by discarding their traditional lifestyles, some have returned to a traditional life-style and yet others are using western technology, such as radio broadcasting to reinforce and spread their own culture.

results.title: The Boy & the island: Christopher Koch, Tasmanian novelist
results.creator_credit: John Muirhead and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A profile of novelist Christopher Koch including readings from his work and beautiful Tasmanian landscape scenes. This program is shot in colour with some black and white sequences and scenes from his novels are performed.
results.title_for_label: The Boy & the island: Christopher Koch, Tasmanian novelist

results.title: Teach Tiwi proper way
results.creator_credit: Rhonda Barker, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The elders of the Tiwi people on Melville and Bathurst Islands have been concerned that their traditional way of life will die out with this generation and so they have instigated bilingual, bicultural education in the local schools, so that the children now learn the Tiwi language and cultural tradition as well as English.

results.title: For better, for worse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Many Australian men go to the Philippines in search of a wife as marriage to an Australian is considered an escape from a poverty-stricken future by many Filipinas. This program interviews some of these women and their husbands who live in and around Darwin about their expectations and their lives since. Those interviewed have enjoyed successful marriages, but there are are others who have not been so lucky.

results.title: The Borrowers. Series II
results.creator_credit: John Henderson, Grainne Marmion and Working Title Films
results.brief_description: The Clock family, Pod, Homily and Arietty are beginning to find living with their “Borrower” relatives a strain, particularly with the return of Ditchly and Ilrick, Aunt Lupy’s two obnoxious and evil sons. The Clocks, and their friend Spiller, make a dangerous journey to find a new home in the model village of Little Fordham. Can they survive the cruel tricks of Ditchly and Ilrick, and manage to avoid capture by the evil Mrs. Driver? With the help of their “giant” friend George, and their own resourcefulness, the Borrowers experience many adventures down drains, in boats and balloons. Excellent special effects make this video a special treat for young and old.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Henderson, Grainne Marmion and Working Title Films

results.title: Kidnapped
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In the late 19th Century thousands of South Sea Islander people were kidnapped and taken to Northern Queensland as “kanakas”, slave labourers, to work on the sugar plantations. This documentary traces the history of the Pacific people in Australia and includes interviews with descendants of the slave-labourers, both in Queensland and the South Pacific. With the advent of the White Australia Policy many thousands of South-Sea Islanders were deported from Australia, but many others fled the authorities and lived in the Queensland bush. Their children and grandchildren now form a strong Islander community in and around the city of Mackay in Queensland.

results.title: Invitation to a wedding
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Joanna Konwicki and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
An old Polish man looks back at his arrival in Australia. He describes his evacuation from a refugee camp in Germany; his work as a labourer on arrival in Australia; his marriage to a Polish woman and their eventual divorce. Simultaneously we watch a contemporary second-generation Polish-Australian couple getting married: Polish ritual and ceremony amidst an Australian landscape. The old man despairs over his ruined love, his hard life and hopes that the next generation can avoid his heartbreak. The narration is from Tadeurz Kempas’ autobiography “Metamorphoses”. The video was filmed amongst Hobart’s Polish community.

results.title: The Bolshoi Theatre: 200th season
results.brief_description: First established in 1776 in Moscow, the Boilshoi Theatre has hosted 200 annual seasons of ballet and opera. This documentary celebrates the history and nostalgia of this wonderful Russian theatre in its 200th season with excerpts from several ballets and operas, along with archival stills, newsreels and commentary. Credits in Russian with English narration.

results.title: What's mad to you? Part 1: Glimpses from psychiatrists
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first in a two-part series, this program looks at the stigma associated with mental illness, particularly in relation to migrants who have different value systems. A number of psychologists and psychiatrists from a wide variety of ethnic backgrounds talk about the problems as they see it. The patient’s point of view is also presented by a small group who talk about how they overcame their resistance to seeking psychiatric help.

results.title: The Bolshoi Ballet in the Park
results.creator_credit: John Vernon, Colin Nears, National Video Corporation, BBC-TV and Entertainment Corporation Concerts and Arts
results.brief_description: This spectacular performance by the artists of the Bolshoi Ballet took place at the Battersea Pavilion, London in 1986 with The Orchestra of London conducted by Alexander Kopylov and artistic direction and choreography by Yuri Grigorovich. The program consisted of: 1. Les Sylphides (Chopin) - Natalia Bessmertnova, Lyudmila Semenyaka, Nina Semizorova, Alexei Fadeyechev. 2. Spartacus Act II (Khachaturian) - Eric Moukhamedov, Natalia Bessmertnova, Alexei Lazaryev, Alla Mikhalchenko. 3. Sleeping beauty (Tchaikovsky) pas de deux - Nina Araniashvili, Leonid Nikonov. 4. La Bayadere (Minkus) solo - Mikhail Tsivin. 5. Swan lake (Tchaikovsky) pas de deux - Nina Semizorova, Alexei Fadeyechev. 6. The Golden age (Shostakovich) - Natalia Bessmertnova, Erik Moukhamedov. 7. Spring waters (Rachmaninov) - Maria Bylova, Leonid Nikonov. Don Quixote (Minkus) - Lyudmila Semenyaka, Yuri Vasyuchenko, Tatiana Bessmertnova, Tatiana Golikova.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Vernon, Colin Nears, National Video Corporation, BBC-TV and Entertainment Corporation Concerts and Arts
